text: Stygean darkness. Wet CLICKING SOUNDS. A BEAM of purplish ULTRA-VIOLET LIGH reveals a mosaic of moving forms... COCKROACHES. They ski restlessly under the beam's intensity. SERIES OF SHOTS -- UV Beam passing over various parts of the space. Pipe web walls, girders -- all covered with the insects. Thousands them.

Innards of steel. A vast maze of tunnels. A GROUP OF FIGURES advances through the tunnels with hand UV lamps. The figures are dressed in gray air-tight NEOPRENE SUITS, their faces hidden by skin tight MASKS and bug-like NIGHT VISION GOGGLES. In the dense silence, respirator valves H CLICK at the corner of their lips in mechanical rhythm. The scene has a dream-like, choreographed quality.
Eerie, aquatic green.  The horde of insects appear to be kind of sea-life, crawling over the floor of a dead ocean

From their midst appears another FIGURE, its neoprene sui flat WHITE.  Female, clearly the TEAM LEADER. She carries a stainless steel CONTAINER filled with twent small compartments, each bearing a large, heavy-shelled r with a different BARCODE on their back. JUDAS ROACHES. She kneels and opens the
TCHK!! A dozen of the Judas roaches are released.  They s through into the area.

react instantaneously.  In a rustle of tiny legs, they be to stream toward the Judases. Jostle and fight each other for position to mate with the They even crawl over the Team Leader in an effort to reac the Judases.  The Team Leader makes no effort to brush th off.  Patient, almost godlike, she watches the MATING.

A MANHOLE has been opened above. CHAINS are dropped down attached by a Team Member to A 100-GALLON DISPOSAL DRUM. REVEAL the floor of the tunnel, carpeted with the still f of the roaches, now all DEAD. The Team Members quietly shovel the tiny corpses into oth disposal drums. At their feet skitter the only survivors of the massacre: the bar-coded Judas Roaches. In a crunch of machinery, the first disposal drum is lift by the chains through the manhole to

MIDTOWN MANHATTAN.  A cacophony of SOUND and LIGHT. Dirty snow drifts over Bryant Park. Emergency lights blin everywhere. A wall of cars sits on Sixth Avenue, stopped dead. Exhaust fumes hang in the air. Jaded TRAFFIC COPS s the cars on crosstown detours. Mounted policemen patrol a line of yellow sawhorses near dozens of Department of Public Health vehicles, angle-par in a military phalanx. A monumental ribcage-like scaffolding has been erected in middle of the street, "sealing" the area with amber plast Inside, UNIFORMED WORKERS take the disposal drum of roach and toss it into one of a number of huge DUMPSTERS. The Team Leader watches from nearby, exhauster.  Her mask off. We see her face: Enthomologist SUSAN WYETH, 28. An ARM gently drapes over her shoulder.

How we doing? She looks over at DR. PETER TYLER, 34, bespectacled.  A HEADSET around his neck, a coat emblazoned with the DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH logo.  He has the look of a man who' just fought a long battle and come out victorious.

We'll see... He offers her a bite of a PAY DAY CANDYBAR.  Susan smiles shakes her head.  She wearily leans against him. Peter looks out as the dumpster filled with roaches is ra by MECHANICAL ARMS into the waiting maw of the dump truck THE SCREEN. DARKNESS. A voice, a somber bas-relief in the darkness.
Strickler's Disease crept into Manhattan like a thief in the night, claiming its first hundred victims before it was even classified.
We FLOAT through a long hospital ward. Past ROWS of illuminated oxygen tents, pulsating softly i the dark like cocoons of light.

Most were children under ten. TRACK past tents.  BODIES OF SMALL CHILDREN inside, wrapp in white sheets, hooked up to IVs or breathing apparatus. Skeletal hands, parched lips, glazed eyes. BELLOWS of respirators push in and out, labored, failing. IMAGE RESOLVES TO A VIDEO ON A SCREEN. PULL BACK to reveal a number of SCREENS, each with a different set of images.  We are in a NEWS VAN.   A TECHNICIAN and DIRECTOR sit watching. The voice belongs to an ANCHORMAN who's now overimposed.
Only after the numbers had reached into the thousands were officials able to identify the carrier of the deadly infection...
Cut to three. The Technician manipulates the controls.  On another scre we see them cut to STOCK NEWS FOOTAGE: regular cockroache crawling on garbage.
Blattida Germanica.  The common cockroach.
(To a RUNNER)
Tell them we're ready for a live feed.
The runner exits the News Van.  Other such vehicles parke nearby.  A CROWD of ONLOOKERS, REPORTERS and a gaggle of PROTESTERS with handpainted signs. Gliding past them, we pick up sound bites...
...an insect that has proven virtually immune to chemical control...
...the announcement by the Health Department that an end to the nightmare has finally... REPORTER 3 is interviewing a Greenpeace PROTESTER who is holding up a photograph of Susan.
...an ex-colleague of Doctor Susan Wyeth...
...Susan has always been opposed to biological tampering. A real advocate for ecological causes, it's not... MOVE past them to further inside of the perimeter...

A NEWS CONFERENCE in progress.  A packed house.  T.V. monitors spaced ever 10 seats or so. In the audience, the MAYOR OF NEW YORK and various CITY OFFICIALS, listening t Peter, speaking at the podium with the ease and enthusias a public servant still untainted by bureaucracy.
While Peter talks, a news title appears at the bottom of screen: PETER TYLER. DEPUTY DIRECTOR, DEPARTMENT OF HEALT
(wrapping up)

...in Nature, evolution is a long, leisurely conversation between an organism and its environment. We, however, did not have the luxury of time... Susan is waiting in the wings. She observes the audience. She notices that the entire front row is composed of CHIL who have survived Strickler's.  Leg and arm braces, facia scarring... He nods at Susan, who takes the podium, adjusting her jac slightly ill at ease in her business suit.  She clears he throat, speaks softly.

With the aid of genetic labs throughout the country, we recombined cockroach DNA with genetic information from termites and mantids. We were able to create a biological counter-agent.  A new ally, if you will... She places a clear container on the podium for all to see
Blattida Traditor.
One of the Judas roaches skitters about in the container.
The "Judas Roach". Cameras FLASH.  MURMURS from the audience.

The Judas is a non-carrier of Stricklers, with a short life-span and heightened pheromone emission. On the back row she can see some ecological hand-painted signs being raised in silent protest. She stumbles for a second, then resumes her speech.
The female is basically a sexual magnet; common males travelled miles and fought for the right to mate with them. The audience is rapt.

When they did, they took away something else we added -- a hormone, passed through sexual congress that causes their metabolism to go into overdrive.  No matter what their food intake, they starved to death in a matter of hours. Now Peter takes the mic.
We've achieved almost total eradication of the roach population.  As of today, the disease has been officially contained. A STANDING OVATION starts and is carried on as we...
in a tub in a dark bathroom. Her business suit crumpled on the bathroom floor.  SOUND of a TV outside.
Sus, come on.  You're missing it.
Nothing grand.  Peter in his shorts at a TV with shitty reception.  He adjusts the disgruntled cable box. He is seen over the TV, giving his address.
Fucking thing! I hope someone's taping this. (Out.)
Susan, come on.  It's really good this time. I got most of the lines out. (No response.)
Sus? Peter sighs. He picks up an open bottle of champagne and two mis-matched ceramic cups, then heads for the bathroom
Life's a bitch. Our 15 minutes came and went and all we got was bad cable... Susan doesn't answer, clearly not in the same high spirit
Hiding from the hard glare of publicity? He notices her crumpled garment on the floor.  He picks i up, puts it up on the hanger.
A shame.  You looked great tonight.
Please.
You did! He sits by the tub.
Do you think we did the right thing?
Taking a cab instead of hiring a limo?
You know what I mean... Peter pours some champagne into the cups.
We did no impact evaluation.  The consequences of...
(sighs)
Is this a Catholic guilt thing...? We hear a NEWSREADER on the TV.
...a flawless strategy which has stopped a potential epidemic in its tracks...
You hear that?  Flawless.
We just don't know. He offers one cup to Susan.  She doesn't take it.
We know we saved lives. He sits closer to her.
There're gonna be a lot of kids running around next year because of you. Beat.  Susan starts to relax. He kisses her.
Who know?  We get lucky, maybe a couple of 'em'll be ours.
(smiling now)
We're down to a "couple" now, huh? She pats the water, beckoning.
Oh, I don't know. People are beginning to talk about us... Still partially clothed, he steps into the bathtub. Susan shakes her head, laughs ruefully.
Don't worry, I'll save your honor. Maybe I'll even marry you. She reaches over, kisses him.
The WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE dimly visible through the rain.
Empty warehouses. Closed businesses. Traffic lights blink on empty streets. Everything seems doomed under the heavy layer of rain.

A DILAPIDATED BUILDING before us. A blazing NEON CROSS ma of the words 'JESUS SAVES' hangs askew from its facade. CRANE to see the ROOFTOP. WHAM! The door to the interior stairs FLIES OPEN and a ta thin CHINESE PREACHER in his sixties lurches out, eyes wi with terror. He looks back down the steps. Something's climbing up fast, casting ominous, complex shadows on the wall. Too many FOOTSTEPS for it to be just one person. The man hurriedly shuts the door and slides a bolt home. Trembling, he backs away as a booming THUD makes the door shudder. Raw, frenzied pounding and scratching follows... something inhuman, determined to break through. The metal surface suddenly buckles and bulges. On the man's white undershirt, a blotch of blood starts t grow.  Needles of rain stab his flesh. He searches wildly for a possible escape. He reaches the edge of the roof: it's five floors down to sidewalk. Two of the hinges on the door come loose, pulverizing the surrounding concrete. WHAM!  The door to the stairs bulges outward as something SMASHES against it again and again.  Frenzied SCRATCHING. The man sprints to the other end of the roof. There, on t adjoining building...
Just one floor below on the building across the alley is suspended PAINTERS' PLATFORM, crowded with paint cans und tarp.  A two-story old EYEWEAR ADVERTISEMENT from the 40' being painted over.

Looks back to the door.  BAM! a tremendous SHATTERING sou LIGHT spills from inside. Two bolts fly in the air, a hin gives. He CRIES OUT in terror. The man gauges the distance between buildings; can he mak it? He takes a few steps back, a few more... Panting hard, he closes his eyes, his chest soaked in blo and rain.

head_text.subj: THE DOOR EXPLODES OUTWARD AND SKIDS ACROSS THE SLIPPERY R

text: Light from inside projects the shadow of wild, busy thing onto the curtain of rain. Weeping with fear, the man desperately tries to hurl hims to the catwalk. It's too far. He FALLS...CRASH!  he hits the platform, knocking boards loose and sending paint cans onto their sides, rolling. bounces, slides off the edge, barely able to grab onto a loose board to save himself from falling. The RAIN blasts down.  The scaffold CREAKS.  He hits the edge, upsetting the cans of paint there. He holds onto the planks with all his might, trying to pu with his feet, but they slide on the wet wall.
Cans bounce off the pavement. White pain blasts all over.
The man's hands slip on the planks, tiring.
The Chinese Preacher's FEET bicycle in the air, unable to find a purchase on the wet brick wall-
is hanging just in front of the painted EYE of the fortie model.  He looks up above him, sees something-
No.  Please, God, no! A SHADOW crosses his face as something looms above him. Suddenly there is a CRACK and the platform tilts complete on one end.
The Chinese Preacher's fingernails dig in, then slip on t wet wood. His hands paw the air.
For a moment his body, silhouetted in the rain, seems suspended in a void. Then he falls backwards.
Impact. His body cracks the pavement. Small pools of rain form on his dead, open eyes. We CRANE to reveal

head_text.subj: A WINDOW ON A BUILDING ACROSS THE STREET

text: CHUY, a young Latino boy. He stares out the window at the Chinese Preacher's body with no discernable emotion. He works a small WIRE SCULPTURE in his hands.

It's a small one-bedroom apartment. An old man sleeps peacefully on a cot: Chuy's grandfather MANNY GAVIOLA, mid 60's, white hair haloes his handsome, benign face. All around him: SHOES, shoes everywhere you look, on the table, on the chairs, on the kitchen counter, on the floo A small altar is illuminated by votive candles. Next to i standing by the window is
We see a blurry vision of The Chinese Preacher's splayed figure in a swirl of color. Chuy's attention focuses on the Preacher's shoes.
(a whisper)
Oxfords, 8 1/2. Black... He looks away from the body and goes back to twisting the wire into shape.
around the preacher, reflects large shadows moving above, and across the neon sign...
hears a strange sound, a rhythmic clicking. His head lifts and what he sees causes his expression to change--there is an uncharacteristic flicker of excitemen his eyes.

We are behind whatever it is that has captured Chuy's attention. TICKETY-TACKETY-TOCK... The strange clicking sound grows louder.  The figure begi moving in some weird, preparatory fashion. Then it steps forward and drops out of frame.
His eyes follow the figure down to the pavement in a slow arc. Chuy puts down the wire miniature and opens the window to a better view.
The Chinese Preacher's body is now being dragged toward t rear of the alley, leaving colored paint smears in its wa

We isolate the boy's face and, on the soundtrack, every o noise FADES AWAY. Chuy reaches for a pair of SPOONS nearby. He begins to click them together. Imitating the strange clicking sound heard a moment ago.
is being pulled into a small, ground-level vent. The only problem is that no human is small enough to squeeze throu this hole.
watches, still clicking with his spoons.

is stuck. One of his legs is through the hole up to the thigh, but the other is folded up unnaturally and pressin against the wall next to the vent. Impossible. There is a silent beat, and then a series of INCREDIBLY VIOLENT TUGS, BAM! BAM! BAM! shaking the Paint-soaked bod like a rag doll.
His spoons stop. His jaw tightens a little as we hear terrible cracking and scraping sounds.
The Chinese Preacher's head and hands disappear into the hole. Bits of clothing, paint and blood stick to the edge the opening.
watches, still fascinated.
(very low)
Funny, funny shoes... He starts a new wire sculpture.

Peter is covered in sweat, running at a good clip around Central Park reservoir. A beautiful day dawns behind him; windows of the Beresford sparkle in the morning sun. Peter outperforms most of the other RUNNERS in the track, steady rhythm evidence of years of practice. Keeping his stride, he runs off the track and past a flock of OLD NUN
Excuse me, ladies... Without slowing down, Peter retakes the path and moves pa them.

Peter finally slows down. He checks his pulse and stops a water fountain. As he drinks, he sees a DERELICT drawing a figure on the sidewalk. The derelict spots Peter.  He picks up his chalk, drifts Intrigued, Peter goes closer to the drawing. An arrow poi to a manhole cover set among the bushes. Peter circles around, trying to make sense out of the lin Then the painted motif finally reveals itself.
A talismanic figure of raw, archetypal power. A few jagge lines form the shape of a MAN IN AN OVERCOAT. His face is little more than a malignant blotch.

A room of half-finished exhibits. A group of SCULPTORS -- most of them undergraduates -- work on a gigantic piece representing a termite mound.  They're supervised by SIRI punkish young Indian research assistant. Susan talks to some of the sculptors about a 100-1 scale clay model of an insect's head.  She gestures to the model's mandible set.
...no, guys, these have to fit perfectly.  No spaces in between. Let me tell you why. Insects have no hands. All they have is this set of mandibles. She grabs the outer mandible set.
See?  This little piggy will grab the prey. Then unfolds a second set...
Then this little piggy will tear it in half... And a third!!!
...and this little one will grind it to a pulp and push it in... all the way into the mouth.  These are precision tools here. Can you remember that? The guys nod.
Good.  Then get it right. A piece of the termite mound is raised above their heads, revealing... ...Peter, at the entrance, still dressed in his jogging sweats. He smiles at Susan.
Peter and Susan walk through.  Peter pulls something from KNAPSACK.  A bottle of medicine marked: METALLININ.
(teasing)
"Baby in a bottle..." He gives it to Susan.

Don't tease. Around them, WORKMEN begin unloading crates of display st as a MAN on a ladder tacks up an "ARCHITECTS OF NATURE" banner. Susan proceeds behind an exhibit representing a honeycomb.  Peter follows as she begins to arrange some t
You know where they get this fertility stuff?  They extract it from the urine of menopausal Italian nuns.
(laughs)
Monks bottle their own wine. Don't they? She gently touches her belly.
Trust me. I've never been this late. Never. She shakes the bottle.
If nun's pee is what it takes... Peter's cellular RINGS from his knapsack. Susan grabs a larvae model from a pile on the floor.
You were the one who ran around with ice in his underwear, don't forget that.
Don't get kinky here... Peter takes the call. Susan cuts away the excess plastic the lid around the honeycomb moldings. The larvae fits perfectly inside.
Okay, meet me out front. (to Susan)
I gotta go. Josh's picking me up in five. see you tonight.
I'll be late. He kisses her and leaves. Susan turns to Siri and the gro working on that sculpture.
Siri, sandblast that thing. It looks like Trump Tower.  Those mounds are supposed to be made of dirt and excretions...
(a wicked smile)
Just like Trump Tower, then.
A Department of Health VAN honks its way through a traffi jam.
Peter's right hand man, JOSH MASLOW -- a young, good-natu can-do guy -- drives.

...So I say "buddy, you have every violation in the book.  Gimme one good reason not to close you down." You know what the Kraut says to me? In the back, Peter finishes changing out of his jogging sweats and into his worksuit.
The blintzes!  "Try the blintzes..."
(distractedly)
Selling your sould for a fistful of carbohydrates...
Not just any carbohydrates, mind you. It was like being on the receiving end of some kind of transcendent oral sex. (honks furiously)
We should get a strobe on this thing. Maybe even a siren.
Yeah, and a loudspeaker so you can yell "Epidemic! Epidemic! You're all going to die!"
The Department of Health van pulls up outside the flophou where the Chinese Preacher died. Peter and Josh get out. COPS push back a few ONLOOKERS. Josh proudly flashes his badge.
Health Department... The cops let them pass.
You really love flashing that thing, don't you?
Hey. I'm a short guy. Waddaya want? Two cops -- WOYCHEK and RICE -- approach, in no real hurr
Peter Tyler, DOH. You gentlemen were the first on the scene?
(gestures to Rice)
We were both on patrol, saw this paint mess. Then I looked through that cellar window. We both did...
You gone in?
No. We waited.
Good. Peter peeks through a narrow cellar window on the floor. Through the oily, smeared window, a ghostly array of PALE FACE AND HANDS appears, startling him.
(to Josh)
Get the EMT's in there, now.

PARAMEDIC AMBULANCES rush in. Sirens at full blast. Stepping out of the building across, Manny walks next to Chuy, who holds his hand. The old man carries a box full shoes. Chuy looks back at the cop circus, amused.
C'mon Chuy, we're gonna be late. (discreetly crossing himself)
Cops are bad news. Don't look at them. He gently pulls his grandson's hand and moves briskly awa
uses an iron bar, and breaks a padlocked cellar door. A h stench emanates from inside. The cops cover their noses.

Peter and Josh enter a dingy, dungeon-like cellar, illuminated only by bug zappers and emergency lights. Eve door and window has been nailed shut or sports a heavy-du padlock. Peter and Josh walk through the dismal scene. In sharp contrast with the dirt-smeared walls, we see shi metallic SEWING MACHINES and swatches of cloth appliqued a FUNNY BUNNY cartoon character. Josh examines the label stitched into the collar. It read PROUDLY MADE IN USA.
Jesus. His light hits a group of quivering, skeletal CHINESE IMMIGRANTS, standing in a tight group against a wall.
(from the outside)
They look real sick, don't they?
Carrying boxes full of terrarium material, Susan and Siri ride an antiquated cage-steel elevator.  No floor buttons just an old-fashioned hand-activated lever.
...as long as they're ready for the opening I don't care, just tell them that.
I'm on it.  Don't worry. (Beat)
Look, Susan...I don't mean to pry, but... I kinda overheard you and Peter.
(Smiles ironically)
Watch your step, Siri.  Your grant could be on the line here.
I just...well, I had this cousin in Delhi.  She was having problems, too. She, ah...
What?
She used a baster. Susan looks at her.
Not a big one.  I mean, it was like a turkey baster.
Oh, Jesus. She tries to stop the elevator at the fourth floor, but it rises just a little too far.
Come on, darlin'... Susan has to jimmy the lever till the elevator falls level to the floor.
(continues)

She kept it under her bed. Thing is, it kinda worked.  I mean, she had to hide it from her husband, but... A pair of young boys, RICKY and DAVIS, sit on the floor outside Susan's lab door.  A crumpled paper bag and a sho box sit beside them.
What's this?
Oh, right... They been here since noon. I told them you're real busy. Susan smiles at the boys, who stand when they see her.
Hello.
You the bug lady, right? Siri chuckles.
(smiles)
I suppose so. Ricky raises and shakes the paper bag.
We're here to deal.
SUNLIGHT slants in to illuminate an incredible array of l and mounted dead INSECTS, trapped in turn-of-the-century glass fronted cabinets. Davis puts his nose up against on fascinated.
Metaxonycha Godmani, Trigonopelastes Delta.  Field Butterflies.  Have you been upstate? She examines the boys' findings, mostly rag-tag specimens of battered butterflies.
Avenue B.
(sadly)
I guess they got lost in this city.
So, you wanna buy em?
There's extra wings in the bag. Siri lingers in the background.
You guys have done a nice job.  How bout five dollars?
(dismayed)
That's it?
(to Ricky)
Show her the weirdbug. He indicates the shoebox-
Cost a dollar just to look.
It's a great bug.  We kinda broke it a little... Siri impatiently points at the wall clock-
Fellas, I'll tell you what...ten dollars for everything.  Plus a killing jar, some tweezers and mounts so the next bunch you catch will be in better shape.
Deal!
You crazy! That's the best!!
Bug's almost dead anyway. Susan holds out two five dollar bills.  The boys can't resist.  Davis grabs the money-
Thanks, lady. Ricky gives a last possessive look to the shoe box, then follows Davis out. Siri crosses to the window and wrestles to close it.
Ten dollars? Susan places all the kid's items -including the shoebox- a wastebasket.
Alphabet City kids- there's much worse things they could be selling. Siri hits the window frame with a paperweight, gets it ha way down.
I hate this fucking window...
CRANE TO a nearby alley. A GAUNT MAN IN AN OVERCOAT stands in the shadows, looking at Siri working on the window. As a streetlamp lights up, he backs up into the shadows.
Religious slogans and posters are hung everywhere in what used to be the lobby of a men's hotel.  A hand-lettered s

PARAMEDICS are leading a number of ill CHINESE IMMIGRANTS from the cellar door seen earlier.  Many are brought out STRETCHERS. DOH staff put tags on their wrists. Peter examines a PALE OLD MAN on a stretcher while simultaneously talking to Josh.
(to Josh)

There's plenty of systemic infection already, so as soon as we get a preliminary reading, start them on anti-biotics. You saw this? Peter flicks on his penlight, examines the Old Man's eyes One of them is completely bloodshot. Then he shows Josh the gums. They're bleeding.
Internal hemorrage. 2 our of 5 have it.  No definite signs of TB, but we'll quarantine them a week just to make sure.
Immigration's gonna love you for that.
Tell them to send flowers to the usual address.
Peter pushes back a sheet hung across a doorway.
A tiled nightmare. Concentration camp-cozy. A pile of old rusting sewing machines clutter the floor, spilling oxide to a central grate.
Two shifts, people rotating from bed to work.  One toilet. We're in Wal-Mart hell, here. Josh swats a fly.
Did they get the sleazebag who owns this place?
Triad, Chinese Mafia. They bring people from Yunan. Slave labor... (eyes his notebook)

Reverend Harry Wong, a preacher had the flophouse fronting for them. No sign of him. An overhead door is opened. Daylight streams in. Peter sp YANG, an Asian cop, talking to a CHINESE WOMAN lying on a stretcher which hasn't been moved yet.  She is hollow-eye near death.  Her hand weakly hangs on to the cop as if fo dear life.

Tell her she's going to be alright. We'll take care of her. Peter kneels next to her, looking at her and nodding whil Yang translates. The woman mutters again, tears of fear i her eyes.  Yang shakes his head.
She's delirious.  Keeps saying the "Dark Angels" are coming for her. She says they took some of her people away.
Dark Angels?
(Shrugs.)
Probably a gang.  Chinese people, man. They come up with some wacky stuff. They pull the stretcher out through the open overhead doo and into an

The stretcher is rolled into a waiting vehicle, its light flashing. Unseen by them, on a brick wall, nearly buried graffiti, is a crude DRAWING. It is of the same, odd figure Peter saw drawn earlier.  T OVERCOAT MAN.

Susan and Siri, both wearing Walkman headsets, deftly mou BUTTERFLIES and other INSECTS onto display boards for the exhibit. Rain is blowing in through the half-open window. Their movements are precise and lyrical, the colors and designs of the insects are beautiful. We understand how you can get lost in this world.  Susan works steadily, a partially-eaten PAY-DAY BAR and the wrappers of several others are evidence of her dinner. A PAGER goes off in Susan's lab coat. She takes off her headset; CLASSICAL MUSIC leaks from her headphones. On the PAGER's LCD screen the message reads: LATE TONIGHT. PETE. Susan puts the pager down. Goes to close the window. There is a loud, angry BUZZING sound.
Siri? (louder)

Siri?! Siri pulls her headset off; HEAVY METAL MUSIC leaks from headphones. The BUZZING sound again. We PAN across the various bugs a mounting implements till we come to rest... ...on the SHOEBOX the boys gave Susan. Something rattles wildly inside.

...the fuck? Susan crosses to the trash bin, picks the box out. It vibrates on her hand, then becomes quiet, something moves inside. She slowly opens the lid. The bottom of the box is littered with two inches of shre newspaper. Crumbs of bread and some rice-krispies can be spotted here and there: a kid's idea of a comfy critter's nest. She moves her free hand closer.
(To Siri)
Can you...? Suddenly and INSECT big as her hand springs out of the shredded paper nest and tries to grab on to her! Minute pieces of paper fly through the air!! Susan slaps the lid back down.
(a scared whisper)
Could you...help me...?
Siri comes over as Susan grabs steel tongs and a cork dissecting board.
I'm gonna pull it out and I want you to pin it down, okay?
What is it?

I have no idea.  Are you ready? Siri nods, pins in hand.  Susan opens the lid and grabs t nymph with the tongs.  The creature goes berserk, flailin its spindly limbs, BUZZING and CROAKING, a milky substanc FOAMING out of its body.
Oh my God... Susan deposits the insect onto the corkboard. Siri tries to get a hold of it; but it twists out of the tongs and wraps its coarse legs around her hand!! A spide trapping a sparrow.

Shit!! Get it!  Get it! SNAP!  It bites her hand between index and forefinger. Susan pins the insect into the corkboard. It spins furiou like a crazy LP record. Susan gets a grip on it again with the tongs.  Siri uses pins to secure it down.
(Noticing Siri's hand)
It bit you.
No shit.
leans to get a closer look at the NYMPH: Deep dark brown, flat as a pancake, one rear leg broken, lower tail smashe It squirms helplessly now, looking pitiful under the hars overhead light.
This wing configuration. I've never...
(looking at her injury)
Fuck! It broke the skin...
And they're not fully developed.  This thing's not even an adult. The nymph continues to HISS and FOAM, struggling against steel pins. Susan looks closely at the insect's belly.
My God.
What? Susan gestures to look.  Siri stares down at
where a SET OF VALVES on its underside click in and out.
It's breathing.
shakes her head.
That's impossible.  Insects don't...
I know. (Picks up a SCALPEL)
Help me get a sample. Susan touches her scalpel to the nymph's leg. The nymph CLICKS nervously.
Hold on, big guy, hold on... She traps the nymph down and CUTS THE LEG OFF. A painful, agonized BUZZ echoes around the room.

Susan attaches the insect's leg to a samll holder. It is frozen in a swirl of dry ice. The brittle leg is then mounted in a LASER MICROTOME. Bit bit, the machine executes MICROSCOPIC WAFER CUTS. Siri is making slides out of each section. A series of MICROPHOTOGRAPHIC IMAGES flash onto the scree In the background we hear the high-pitched BUZZ- We see the lights from the mounting room through a glass brick wall.
We see the nymph slowly squirming in the FG, then RACK FO to the rain-spattered WINDOW. Suddenly the OVERCOAT MAN is standing on the windowsill! The window is lifted effortlesly from the outside.
prepares a blue solution and places two drops on each sme slide. Reflected in the glass brick behind her we see the man mo across the room.

seen only through rippled glass and reflections, moves through the lab. His body STEAMS lightly from the rain. His movements are quirky, spastic. The man observes the imprisoned insects with curiosity. He comes to the nymph, pinned and mutilated on the workta The nymph CLICKS and CHITTERS excitedly, as if communicat with the man. He looks up at the worklight.  It seems to bother him. WHUMP!!! In a blur of motion, he SMASHES the light bulb.
watches the smear slide.  The blue droplets begin to CHAN COLOR once in contact with the leg section...
Hold on a second... ...slowly turning a deep green.
What? Then, THREE LARGE BEETLES fly into the room. Siri looks at Susan. Susan gets up, hesitant, signals for Siri to stay. We FOLLOW Susan into the mounting room.

She walks in, barely able to see her hand in front of her face. The window facing the street is wide open, rain blowing i Something CRUNCHES under her feet.  She bends down, looks She's stepped on the broken glass of the lightbulb. The floor is alive with various INSECTS -- crawling, hopp flying away from their displays, which have been opened. The nymph is gone from the board! She looks under the work table the nymph was on. We LOWER as we TRACK BACK with her.  Something is folded in the corner of the ceiling behind her, camouflaged in t shadows, clinging impossibly to the wall. THE OVERCOAT MAN. He lowers himself with silent grace. Susan whirls.
Silence.
Susan? Susan GASPS, startled.  We SHIFT to see Siri at the door.
Call security.
The last DOH van takes off under the heavy rain. Across the street, Chuy looks down from his apartment win

Chuy sits at the window, twisting wire into a human-like figure.  MOVING past him, we see a group of other WIRE FIGURES on the table, backs of chairs, lamps, everywhere. Manny sits at the kitchen table. He IGNITES a can of shoe polish with a match, then lights a cigarette off the flam He puts the cigarette in his mouth and proceeds to polish pair of shoes. A SILLY SHOW plays over the TV.

Not too little, not too much. You rub it in, around and around like this. Let the leather take it. Manny leans tiredly against the table. He looks fatigued and in pain. He takes a small pill and places it under his tongue.
You watching? You should learn to work the shoes. You're good with your hands... Manny shoots a glance over to his grandson.
Chuy...you gonna get all wet. Chuy doesn't pay attention, just stares out at the street
Did you look at the story book I got you? Manny lifts a brightly colored CHILDREN'S BOOK.
Our Animal Friends.  Can you say that, Chico?  "Friends"? Nothing from Chuy.
The building across the street. Yellow DOH tape at the entrance.

A friend is the one you can trust.  When you are with a friend, no matter where in the world, you are at home. A FIGURE moves out of the shadows and totters in the rain toward the entrance.  It is the OVERCOAT MAN, barely visi in the rain.
In this city. A friend is a hard thing to find...
His face shows a bit of animation.
Funny Shoes... Manny looks up from the book.
Alli.  Mr. Funny Shoes. Manny comes over, looks out.
The figure has disappeared into the dark front of the boarded-up building.
No one is there. Is empty. Chuy doesn't respond.  Manny turns the boy's face to his.
Chuy, listen to me.  They have Jesus on the cross, but that is not a holy place. You understand? Chuy looks at him blankly.  Manny sighs; he knows he does
Ah, Nino.  God only knows what goes on in your head, eh? He pats the boy on the head, then goes back to work. Chuy turns back to stare at the street.
Mr. Funny Shoes...
The D.O.H. Van pulls up in front of a modest Pre-war building. Josh and Peter climb out. Peter is reviewing a roster.
Josh, what was Immigration's countdown? Josh hands Peter a plastic bag with his sweat clothes and running shoes.
Thirty-three workers. Peter hands him the roster.
There are thirty five listed in the reverend Wong's roster...
Shit. Peter walks up the front steps.
Remember what that woman said, about people being taken? Check with the copsin the area.
Peter enters the apartment, which has long since been remodeled with a nicer couch and a bigger TV with slightl better reception.
Sus? No answer.  He notices the dining room table is filled wi yellowed FILES, all marked JUDAS TRADITOR.
(Looks around once again)
Susan?
Peter comes in to find Susan sitting in a chair before a dryer, quietly watching laundry whirl within.
(Regarding the laundry.)
Thought it was my week for that.
(Shrugs.)

I needed to think. It was either this or the weather channel. Peter walks over, kisses her.  He notices an open book of INSECT MORPHOLOGY on her lap. There's a FULL COLOR PHOTOGRAPH of an OOTHECA -- an insect eggcase.
Peter folds laundry into his/her piles.  Susan paces.
This thing was the size of my fist, Peter!! That's off the charts!
Okay. So you lost a great specimen-
Don't you get it? It's more than that. Peter takes a bedsheet. Susan helps him fold it.

You know why insects don't grow larger? Because they don't have a complex respiratory system. What I saw did. It had lungs. Peter walks backward with his end of the sheet.  The two begin to fold it together.
Evolution doesn't work that fast. Something pushed that thing to take the leap. We need to find another specimen.
We? As they fold the sheet, they move closer together.
I did a PH test on its tarsal pads. The folding of the sheet has brought them almost face to face. Susan finishes folding herself.
There's only two species who match the enzymes I found.  One's a leaf-cutter ant in the Amazon... She has his full attention now.
The other we released here two years ago.
A TAXI CAB makes a U turn and cruises on.
Susan ignores the yakking Armenian DRIVER as she scans the buildings and empty lots-
Avenue B... again! Maybe you got wrong letter, uh? The cabbie looks up at a Manhattan street map glued over his head on the roof of the cab.
Keep going. We'll tell you when to stop...
Maybe they lied to you.

Even if they did... that's all we have, isn't it? The cab cruises past the tenement buildings, nondescript stores, junked cars and rubble-strewn lots. It stops before a traffic light. A LEERING HOMELESS GUY with a greasy rag and greasier cleaning solution approaches the windshield.

No... Oh, shit. Get away, you Turk! The Homeless guy begins wiping/smudging the windshield with his dirty rag. The driver sends him away. The light turns green.  The Driver accelerates, turning on the windshield wipers to expunge the smears left by the guy. Susan sees something.
Pull over!
What...? Susan motions excitedly.  The Driver pulls over. Susan gets out.
Susan rushes over, removes something from the windshield wiper. A BUTTERFLY, its wing pinned under the rubber flapper. She holds it in her palm, then looks up at Peter.
Metaxonycha Godmani.
So? Susan looks around.  Just ahead is an empty LOT surrounde a wooden fence plastered with flyers for rock bands and performance artists. An identical BUTTERFLY perches on the edge of a board.
Susan and Peter walk through waist-high GRASS of a small urban wilderness.  Dozens of BUTTERFLIES flutter around t from the weeds.
If you want your money back, forget it! Peter and Susan look up.  The voice comes from a RAMSHACK CLUBHOUSE, built of wood scraps and cardboard.
We already spent it! Susan walks forward.
We're here to deal. Long beat.  The door to the clubhouse swings open.
A BLUR of subway cars goes by with an ear-pulverizing SOU At the end of the platform, Davis untwists a wire around busted lock of a locker room door. Peter paces nervously nearby.
Here, let me... He starts on it himself. Meanwhile, Ricky stares at a PHOTOGRAPH Susan has given to him:  a ribbed, tortoise- brown colored EGGCASE.
You sure you didn't see one of these?
Gross. What is it?
An "Ootheca". An eggcase. It probably had more, uh "weirdbugs" inside.
(shakes his head)
No way. I see one of those, I'd puke. Davis opens the door with a CLICK.
A dark, abandoned LOCKER ROOM once used for transit worke Susan and Peter walk in with the boys, nervous in the off limits area.
It was in that corner over there. Davis points to a bank of dented metal LOCKERS.
Sucker was fast, man. (Picks up a pipe.)
Had to take it out with one a these.
Okay, guys.  We'll take it from here. Peter hands Ricky some money. The boy looksdown at it slyly.
Make it ten an' we won't tell the cops you're here. Peter regards the little scam artist dryly.

Let's keep it at five and I won't condemn your clubhouse. Peter hands him a couple of dollars more. The two boys take off. Peter removes a PENLIGHT from his pocket. Dust covers everything. A forest of COPPER TUBING and PIP where the sinks used to be.
inspects the floor. It's littered with cheap objects: chipped combs, used rubbers, soggy newspapers, smeared heroin syringes. Something shiny catches his eye. He picks it up.
(quietly)
Look, a broken tooth... Something rustles nearby. He notices an old, rotting poster on the back wall.  It seems ODDLY TEXTURED somehow.  He walks toward it.

kneeling, pushes aside a dented trash bin. Behind it, the is a cabinet with rusty sliding doors. A SUBWAY TRAIN RUMBLES by outside, the sound echoes off the tile walls. Susan forces the door back. She peeks through the opening Her face stares back at her from a dirty pocket mirror. She starts pulling something out.
at the oddly texture wall.  He shines the penlight at it. ...and is met with a FLUTTER OF WINGS.  MOTHS, perfectly camouflaged against the poster on the wall, whiz past him Peter recoils.
You okay? He nods.

turns back to her locker.  She withdraws a cheap PLASTIC NECKLACE from it.  As she removes it, it breaks.  A coulp beads fall away... ...rolls under the locker... ...and BOUNCE -- once, twice, thrice -- each time going deeper till they comes to a stop. Susan peers where the beads fell.

There's something under here. Peter comes over, kneels by her. Susan takes a handful of beads and throws them at the base of the locker. CAMERA TRACKS to follow one of them. It rolls all the way under. A moment later, from some interior space, the sound of it BOUNCING on cement. He shines his light inside.
Very dark. A highlight glints off a shell-like surface. The light barely touches it. THE WHOLE SURFACE BACKS AWAY. Peter drops the penlight.  It gets stuck in a jutting pie of concrete.
Shit. Peter tries to get his hand in
But he cannot reach the light. It is literally inches fro his fingers...
Let me try.  My hands are smaller. She kneels and goes for it.

Her hand reaches for the penlight. She barely touches it.  The penlight spins around.  Its l now illuminates... THE FACE OF A MAN.  Unseen by Susan.  Terrifying in its d like simplicity.  In the darkness, its features seem indiscernable, inert, almost frozen in a perfectly symmetrical pattern. It regards the spiderlike movement of Susan's fingers.
face squinches with the effort.
Honey, just leave it.
No, there's...
As Susan's hand moves closer, the strange Face begins to TREMBLE. A CLICKING SOUND. Susan's hand is almost there.

reaches further. And suddenly A BEAM OF LIGHT cuts through the darkness. Their vision resolves. The figures of two MTA COPS stand before them:  ERNEST, 50, burly and bull-necked; and LEON -- African American, 45, more formidable than fat.
(Wearily)
Now don't tell me.
Susan's hand withdraws.
You lost a token, right?

SHH-SHH-SHH.  A felt rag is expertly being pulled across set of pristine black shoes. REVEAL Leonard sitting like a king in a chair, getting hi shoes shined by Manny.  He leans back laconically while arguing with Peter. Ernest examines the ootheca picture.
Look, I showed you my badge...
Yeah, and you gonna have to show me a lot bigger one you wanna go down there. That's the old maintenance grid, Doc. Swiss cheese: tunnels, tracks...
The Department of Public Health...
...should know better'n to go sneakin' around my turf...
Fine.  You want me to call your supervisor?
Please do.  He's a lonely guy. Uninterested, Leonard looks over to Susan and Chuy.
She leans against the wall, inspects her dirty hand. Erne gives her his handkerchief.
Gucci.  Flat pump. She looks down at Chuy, who sits nearby, holding a PAIR O SPOONS.

Your shoes. She stares down at her shoes.  Gucci flat pumps, all righ Susan smiles. Just then, a SUBWAY TRAIN pulls up.  The doors open, disgorging passengers. Chuy flips into action.  He starts playing his spoons, CLICKING them together, slapping them against his knee. Susan watches in wonder as the boy begins to use the spoo to IMITATE the different rhythmical step patterns of the VARIOUS COMMUTERS: The rolling, comical gait of A FAT MAN the lithe haughty step of A PRIM LADY.
(Laughs.  To Chuy.)
That's wonderful!  What grade are you in? Chuy doesn't answer.
No school. Shoes're all Chuy knows about. Ernest discreetly points to his forehead.
(immediately)
He's special.
He can imitate anything, you just watch him.
(Irritably, to Leonard)
Excuse me, I'm talking to you.
No, you talkin' at me. Leonard hands Manny a $5.00 bill for the shine, gets up a walks past Peter as if he were invisible.
(discreetly, to Susan)
Is there some reward for this?
I guess that could be arranged. Ernest smiles, pockets the ootheca picture.
For Chrissakes.  You gonna lay a two- bit bureaucratic, territorial number on me?

You wanna keep up the conversation, you best come back with the proper permits and the right attitude. Leonard saunters away with Ernest in tow. Peter shakes his head angrily.  He takes Susan by the arm heads off in another direction. Chuy, without watching, clicks his spoons to the imitatio their steps.
Susan and Peter walk up the stairs; Peter still fumes.
You give someone a fucking uniform and... Did you hear how he talked to us?
I heard how you talked to him.
Oh, so I'm the bad guy now? Susan spares him an ironic look.
He was just doing his job.
Fine, then I'm the bad guy. Jesus! At the top of the stairs they're completely engulfed by sunlight.
He wants a permit, I'll get him a permit.

A train blurs by. A FLASHLIGHT BEAM over dirty gravel.  TILT with the beam see Ernest walking his beat past TRACKS and GIRDERS.  Hul out-of-service SUBWAY CARS surround him. He shines his li on the ootheca picture and then around him at the walls. A SOUND catches his attention.  A RUSTLING. He notices something off to a corner, walks over to it. A SHINY BROWN LUMP in the corner, covered in garbage. He touches the lump with his shoe.  It STIRS slightly. He touches it again... ...and a PAIR OF LEGS suddenly LASH OUT, kicking at him reflexively. Ernest jumps back. Another SET OF LEGS emerges... Oddly enough, Ernest relaxes.

Chrissakes... He grabs the surface of the lump, and pulls it.  We see t it was just a SHINY BROWN TARP. Underneath, a group of THREE HOMELESS PEOPLE -- emaciated toothless -- sleeping intertwined for warmth. In the dim light, they almost seem like a single organism.
Guys, c'mon. The Homeless People stare back at him mutely.  Ernest sta getting annoyed.
I told you to stick by the maintenance area.
Nah... It's private property now. Ernest looks at her, confused.
He eats down there.
Who?
The Stickman.
Long John. The homeless man points.  Ernest turns his light. Another SILHOUETTE of the OVERCOAT MAN drawn on the wall. arrow below it points east.
Graffiti artist, uh? (To Homeless People)

Look guys, just get off my beat, you hear?  Get moving. Ernest hustles them out.  The homeless people glare at hi pick up their things and head into the gloom. Ernest watches them go.  He turns back to the graffiti painting of The Stickman.

Ernest walks deeper into the tunnels. Dusklight slants in weakly from grates above. He stops as a RUMBLE is heard ahead of him  He ducks into recess in the wall.  The RUMBLE grows LOUDER, LOUDER. A SUBWAY TRAIN curves around the bend up ahead, its HEADLIGHTS raking the opposite wall to reveal... A FIGURE crouched over something. We hear CHOMPING and SWALLOWING sounds.
Squinting to see over his flashlight beam.
Hey, buddy! No answer.  Just the wet sounds of food getting chewed an ingested.  Ernest is revolted.

Get off my track... The crouching figure lifts its head and looks around in a unusually quick BLUR OF MOTION.  It's the OVERCOAT MAN. Another distant RUMBLE. Ernest's clothes flutter in the p of hot wind that signals an approaching train. Ernest pulls a CAN OF MACE from his belt, begins to advan The Overcoat Man stands up. Ernest stops in his tracks. For he sees that the Overcoat Man is holding a large OBJE in his arms. Something wet and shiny with blood. A dead dog. The Overcoat Man drops the animal.  It rolls slowly down chest... ...and is briefly caught BY ANOTHER SET OF ARMS EXTENDING FROM HIS TORSO.
Sweet Jesus... The Overcoat Man lets the animal fall to the ground.  He begins walking toward Ernest. Ernest backs away. The Overcoat Man LEAPS on him just as the SUBWAY TRAIN RO
CRACK! Ernest's body is twisted and crunched by powerful arms. Through the strobing windows we see Ernest enveloped by t dark figure, then raised above, taken away.
The can of mace rolls next to the track as the TRAIN CLEA The track is empty again.
We PAN across the banner:  'ARCHITECTS OF NATURE'.

EXHIBITS under glass set up throughout the room: Insect chambers and vaults of great complexity, etc. An opening night CROWD of affluent MUSEUM PATRONS.  All tuxedoes and painted smiles.  Some peremptorily peruse th displays; most just camp out at the buffet table. Peter enters, dressed in his worksuit.  He scans the room, sees Siri leaning against a wall by the buffet table, drinking an orange juice.  He goes over to her.
Heya. (Kisses her on the cheek.)
Where's the boss? Siri gestures to the far end of the room.  Susan stands alone, sipping a chardonnay by an ANT MOUND exhibit.
Ant mound. Peter notices Siri seems unusually weary. She covers one of her eyes.
You okay?
It's just a headache.  We were sandblasting Trump Tower here since four this morning.
Maybe you should sit...
I'm fine. Go talk to Susan.  She could use a good word right now. She nods for him to go ahead.  Peter leaves. Siri closes her eyes.  She rubs the bandage around the insect bite on her hand.
approaches Susan.  She's staring through thr glass panes of the exhibit at the crowd of patrons.  In the refraction, their black tuxedoes and evening gowns seem to blend into one another.
Great crowd.
No such thing, baby. She looks over at the crowd congregated around the buffet table.
I get the feeling they came more for the potroast than the apterids.
Fuck 'em.  They don't know what they're missing.
(Distantly)
Right. Peter looks at her.
What's wrong? Susan sighs.
Oh...nothing that a little menopausal's pee daikiri couldn't cure. Least that's what I thought. Peter looks at her, notices that one of her hands is on her stomach.
(genuinely moved)
Oh, no, you were-
I was just late. Susan nods.  Peter takes her hand. They sit by the ant mound.
Ironic, don't you think?  These guys can hatch hundreds of offspring in a single clutch of eggs, right? And here we are...
Susan, we're not b-
Susan? Susan looks up to see Siri standing on the other side of the glass case.
(Weakly.)
I'm sorry.  I think...I need... One of her eyes is completely bloodshot. Her mouth is bleeding. She puts her hand on the case to steady herself. Her fingers leave a STREAK OF BLOOD on the glass.
Siri... Siri collapses.  The exhibit tips over. Peter pulls Susan out of the way just as the exhibit

head_text.subj: FALLS AND SMASHES TO THE GROUND

text: Siri! The room erupts into COMMOTION. Susan and Peter run to Siri, who lies unconscious on the floor. Peter gently turns her over. Siri's BLEEDING from the corner of her mouth.  Just like the Chinese workers in the sweatshop. Tuxedoed people encircle her next to the insect mounds.
An ambulance races down the avenue toward a distant hospital.
Siri is rushed on a gurney toward the Emergency Room. Peter and Susan walk next to it talking to DR. CHRIS RAYMOND, a 35-year old ER physician.
...I think it's some kind of systemic infection, Chris.  I saw a few cases like it yesterday. A sweatshop in Canal.
(to Peter.)
Okay, look.  You better come in with me.  Help me through.
Raymond, Peter, and several other ER STAFF work on Siri, now lying on an operating table.
(To Peter)
All hands on deck, Pete. Remember the dril?
It'll come back to me. RAYMOND inspects Siri's wounded hand.  The bandage has been removed.  The bite-wound is infected and suppurating.  A large red circular RASH around it.
Looks like a Lyme disease rash.
It's not consistent with the internal bleeding. Any idea what bit her? Peter shakes his head.

I think we're gonna need to have that specimen here. An ASSISTANT finishes inserting a catheter down her throat. Blood and fluid leak up through the clear tube. ABOVE THE OPERATING THEATER. Staring down through the circular glass deck, Susan silently observes the procedures.

Salmon-colored LIGHT slants in from sodium vapor streetli PAN through the shadowy room, past Manny's sleeping form Chuy, asleep under a tent made of an old Star Wars blanke A RHYTHMICAL CLICKING SOUND is heard from outside. Chuy pops his head out from under the blanket, listening.
Wearing only his pajama bottoms, Chuy steps out on the fi escape with his spoons in hand. The CLICKING RESUMES from the building across the street.
The barefoot little boy crosses the street, steps through center of the huge PAINT STAIN on the sidewalk. The CLICKING sound comes again.

The CLICKING comes again from inside the flophouse.  It continues a little bit, then stops. Chuy CLICKS his spoons together, mimicking the sound. Beat.  A CLICKING from within again; almost an answer. Chuy ducks under the yellow DOH tape, walks toward the fr of the building. He comes to the boarded entrance.  There is a hole, narro and low in the doorway. Chuy squats, begins to wriggle through it.
Chuy steps into the lobby. The CLICKING comes again, from further inside. Chuy moves to find it.
Bits of STREETLIGHT slant in.  Chuy walks slowly, listeni He steps into the SHADOW of a LOOMING FIGURE.  He turns..
We start on bleeding, nail-pierced feet, then TILT up the twisted body to the face of Jesus, looking down.

stares without emotion at the plaster figure. MOVEMENT to his side.  He turns again. A dimly-lit FIGURE stands before him. Shapes fold and regroup in the darkness, resolving into t tall figure of the OVERCOAT MAN. The Man begins to emit the CLICKING NOISE from under his chin, his whole head VIBRATING. Chuy smiles.  He has a beautiful smile.

Mr. Funny Shoes. He plays his spoons, imitating the sound the figure made. He is answered...but this time, it's from the other side the room. We PAN as he turns. ANOTHER OVERCOAT MAN appears in the shadows. Chuy GIGGLES, delighted.
Susan and Peter.
...you don't even know what you're looking for.
You said that thing was big as your hand.  I don't think I'm going to miss...
Why take the chance?  Just let me go down there with you...
No. Susan glares at him.  Peter sits down by her.
Susan, listen to me:  you handled that insect almost as much as Siri...
It didn't bite me.
I know.  But if it was carrying something...there's a chance you could have been exposed. Susan is silent.

Chris is going to run some blood tests on you.  I want you to stay here till he's absolutely sure you're clean.  Okay? Then you'll call me... You'll catch up with us... Susan looks up at him. Finally, she nods.
We'll be all right, Sus.  I promise. He leans over, kisses her gently.  But Susan seems hardly reassured.
The blue hours before dawn. Laconic movement outside.  Ne York dragging itself out of bed. We FIND Manny fixing some melted cheese sandwiches on a h plate. He addresses Chuy's tented bed behind him.

My father saw me stay in bed, he'd go get a pitcher. Cold water, whoosh, I tell you that's some alarm clock, brrrrr! Manny cuts the bread in four equal sections and arranges in a star-shaped pattern. A breakfast ritual of some kind
Ah! There you go! The way you like 'em, Chu-chu... (He pours a glass of milk.)
We're low on milk, you remind Grampa to pick some up tonight, okay? He walks over to Chuy's tent bed. He pulls the sheets asi His grandson is gone.

Sewage water BUBBLES in huge tanks. A WORKMAN walks down catwalks above the tank, disengaging larger pieces of debris from the filter areas with grappl hooks.  Shoes, tires, rags... A GRINDING SOUND is heard.  The Workman YELLS out to a CONTROL BOOTH above.
Hold up!  We gotta block on filter D. SOUND of the pump coming to a halt. The Workman walks to the filter area.  He sinks his grapp hook into the polluted waters.
Spooky, silent. The grappling hook moves like a scythe to filter... ...past long, soft filaments of RAGGED TISSUE... ...and connects with a LARGER FORM.
The Workman feels the grappling hook connecting.  He give YANK, hooking whatever it is. He begins pulling it up. A PALE FORM bubbles to the surface. The Workman's face goes pale.
Oh, God... A grating VOICE from the control booth is heard over the
What's the problem? It take the Workman a moment to speak.

I think it's a baby! The Workman pulls the form (as if that will do any good) toward the edge of the tank. He bends down, and now gets his first good look at it. The Workman SCREAMS. His grappling hook falls from his hand, into the sewage.
Susan watches Siri from behind a pane of glass.  Siri is connected to a respirator, her vital signs monitored by several machines. Raymond approaches Susan, two cups of coffee in his hands.
How you feeling?
You tell me. He smiles, gives her one of the cups.
Your blood tests were all negative. You checked out. Susan visibly relaxes.  She looks back at the ICU ward.
What about Siri?
She's stable.  I don't think there's any immediate danger, but we'll have to keep her under observation...
You think it's some form of Strickler's, don't you? Beat.  Raymond shrugs.
Pathology's still working on the tissue samples.  If it is...it must be an errant strain.  Shorter incubation period. (Beat.)
I'm sorry, Sue.  We just don't know yet.
At the sink, Susan runs water over her hands, her face, trying to collect herself.  She looks up in the mirror. We see that her eyes are swollen, tear-stained.
She walks out of the ladies room, drying her face with a paper towel. SOUNDS of a nearby argument catch her attention.
...how many times I gotta tell you, man: we can't accept this!
Well, what the hell else am I suppose to do with it? Susan heads in the direction of the voices.
An ORDERLY (JEREMY) argues with an EMT.  Their point of contention:  a small FORM lying on a stretcher.
Take it out back and throw it in the friggin' dumpster!
Not unless somebody signs for it. Susan walks toward them, catches sight of the tiny form. Her eyes go wide.
Oh, my God. Jeremy notices her.
Hey, you can't...
What's your name?
Jeremy...
Okay, Jeremy...go get Dr. Chris Raymond, will you?
Lady...
Did you hear me?  Get Dr. Raymond!
Jeremy hesitates.  But if her tone wasn't enough, the stare she gives him certainly is.
Okay. Jeremy backs away, takes off down the hall. Susan approaches the stretcher.
(To EMT)
Where'd you find it?
Washed up at the filtration plant on Bank street. Some asshole there thought it was a baby. They called us. Susan bends over it.  She covers her mouth and nose at the stench.

It's a lobster, right? But it's not.  What lies on the stretcher before them looks more like a demon from a Brueghel painting. A THREE FOOT INSECT.  It's mephitic, pink-white body is rotten, falling apart.  The head's intact, with strange, large jaws thrown wide open. The chitin on one is half gone.
Josh deposits a backpack full of equipment on the floor, along with a small acrylic cage. Peter trains his FLASHLI into the bank of lockers. Leonard, weary and pissed, looks at his watch.
Better hurry it up, Doc. My shift's almost over. Josh hands him a piece of paper.

Guess someone requested you for overtime...buddy. Peter braces his legs and tries to push the whole bank of lockers clear--the locker section tips and falls with an ENORMOUS BANG, which echoes loudly off the tile walls. Du flies everywhere. When the dust settles and flashlights are focussed on the area of the wall where the lockers stood, we see a LARGE HOLE.
Using a steel probe, Susan examines the dead insect.
Posterior sternites are gone...half the protonum rotted off. Raymond lifts one of the wings.  A CLUMP OF WHITE LARVAE feasts on the flesh underneath.
Maggots...
Near hatching.  Thing must've died about three weeks ago. Susan closes the mandibles and examines them.
Do you have a polaroid?
Water DRIPPING from overhead, ECHOING footsteps- very spooky.  Leonard leads Peter and Josh down the tunnel-
You all watch your step.  We got some burrows goin' down seven stories here.  You fall, I don't wanna have to come pick you up.
(Whisper to Peter)

New York's finest. Monumental archways give way to naves as big as Notre Dam Josh flashes the ultra-violet light over an abandoned underground encampment, made of cardboard walls, electric wiring, elaborate debris kitchens. The walls are complete taken by layer after layer of hand carved initials and messages. Everything from "Kilroy was here" to elaborate quotations from the bible.
There's really people living down here?
Mole people. This section was pretty popular, all the way to Fulton Street... Their flashlights shine in a haze of brown dust. The air heavy.
Substance abusers, mental cases... Then about a year ago, Poof! All gone. Rumors got started... Someone found a couple of stiffs... They work their way down a steep incline. They're covered sweat.
Down here's the land of talk, see? So the wildest version goes the farthest. They mark that area with a sign or a drawing, and its as good as closed. (chuckles)
We had one fella... for years said he was Bela Lugosi. Got him on Geraldo. Peter's cellular rings. He picks up -big static-
Susan's got the phone up on her shoulder, clamped against ear. Raymond's cranking out a bunch of Polaroids. Color s of the insect, from every angle.
It's me. Can you hear me?
(phone, barely audible)
Yeah, barely. We haven't found anything down here. Nothing... Jeremy goes to the fridge for a beer.
I have. The fridge light plays over the large insects jaws. It ma out a few new ridges and valleys. Raymond snaps a couple Polaroids.
I'm on my way. I've got something for you to look at... Susan notices something weird and undefinable about the contours of the claws... But she can't put her finger on it.
We'll be back at the platform in...
20 minutes. If you don't go sight-seeing anymore.
(To phone.)
20 minutes. (Beat.)
Susan? The call is lost. Peter tries to change frequencies, but useless. Peter replaces the phone in his pocket.  He walks off.
Funny.  Shoulda seen some track bunnies by now.
What?
Track bunnies.  Rats.  They're usually around. No one notices the OVERCOAT MAN carving on the wall.
On Manny's dining room table, a heap of unpolished shoes accumulated. The radio is playing a sad, elegiac Tango.
No, no, please understand... I can't wait that long. Looking disheveled and tired, Manny clutches the phone, listening intently.
Please. I write it down. (he writes)
2... 8... 7... 3. What does this mean "case number"? Okay. So, now what?  When can you...? He holds a color snapshot of Chuy sitting on a mailbox.
No, I can't wait...no, listen... Click. Manny slowly hangs up. He stares at his notepad, a the number 2873.
Hijos de puta. He crumples it up, throws it away, crosses to the window, picks up Chuy's last wire figure-
Another human-looking figure, long and thin, but with something slightly off about it. It has six limbs instead of four!
frowns, looks down at the dark flophouse across the stree
Mr. Funny Shoes. Distant thunder is heard.
Manny takes a STRAIGHT RAZOR from the bathroom cabinet, o the blade.

Susan arrives at the stairs leading down to the subway station. A COUPLE passes her on their way up. A sign over the entrance says "STATION WILL CLOSE FOR REP AT 3 PM - TOKENS ONLY". Susan looks around- the area is s deserted, a bit creepy. She takes a deep breath, descends.

Susan pushes through the turnstile, enters the long corri of gleaming tile, a somewhat de-humanizing atmosphere, straight out of a George Tooker painting. Very creepy.  Susan's footsteps ECHO in the empty tunnel. She sneaks a nervous glance over her shoulder- nobody is following her-
Susan observes the locker room door impatiently. A small of REPAIRMEN are dismantling a row of fluorescent lights. She sits and waits.
Peter, Josh and Leonard walk through a darker area. The floor beneath them suddenly changes, becomes tile.
(Sniffing)
Smells like acid. Peter stops, looks around.
Ammonia. Josh walks to the right, where the smell seems to emanate from.  At last they come to
Josh LIGHTS a flare, sets it on the ground, walks ahead. ominous RUMBLE of a subway is heard in the distance. A cracked WATER MAIN above.  Water dribbles to the ground
Peter...
Yeah...?
There's some weird shit here.
Weird shit...?

Take a look. Leonard shines his flashlight ahead. Revealed, quite literally, is a world of shit. LARGE FECES scattered everywhere:  on the floor, hanging sausage-like from the ceiling.  One can almost taste the stench of old ammonia. Peter puts on a rubber glove, inspects one of the fecal stalactites.
Fecal matter, unknown origin: weird shit. (Beat)
Whatever it is, it's not human. Josh breaks off a sample, drops it in a jar with a hard THUNK.  Leonard turns away in distaste.
And it needs some metamucil.

It's raining like hell. Manny approaches the abandoned flophouse. He peeks through the boarded-up front entrance. Right the on the dusty lobby floor, clearer than the larger shoeprints... ...he discovers a trail of tiny, barefoot prints.
Chuy... He kicks experimentally at the planks, but they're far to strong.

Manny explores the opposite face of the building, looking a way in. A DOG is BARKING incessantly. Manny turns. Something moves in the shadows!  Something long and thin, haloed  by the rain. It moves again, the streetlight touching it for a fleetin moment as it totters around to the rear of the building. It's The Overcoat Man! The man hurries past. Manny sprints after him.

Manny comes running around a pile of grocery crates. There is the OVERCOAT MAN. CARGO WORKERS mill around a group of vegetable trucks, unloading produce. The OVERCOAT MAN attracts no attention. Keeping his head down, staying near the shadowed buildings. Jumping and hopping, he skitters into an alley.

Manny has to trot to keep up with the mysterious figure. pauses to take a pill and place it under his tongue. Once it takes effect he moves on. The OVERCOAT MAN has moved past a chainlink fence. How?? It's too high!!! The old man squeezes through a jagged opening. The metal fabric cuts his shirt. On the other side: a dead end. Nowhere to go except for...
Manny lifts it.

Manny lands on his feet with considerable difficulty. He flicks his lighter flame and opens the straight razor. This pipe is carpeted with trash and a thick crust of dir Something moves under a wet newspaper: a thick mass of lo legged spiders dissolve onto the walls and floor. Suddenly...the distant sound of spoons playing.
Chuy... Manny pulls a rosary from his pocket, wraps it around his wrist and crosses himself with the razor... ...then begins to move down the pipe.
Susan examines the Polaroids.  She pulls out a payday bar The crew of repairmen are leaving.
Hey, Lady, all power will be down in five minutes, okay?

Okay.... She munches on the bar. She stops: one snapshot has caugh her attention.  The fridge light illuminated this photogr Susan turns it around... and around... Trying to find something different in the lines. A train roars by. Then she notices it:
The closed jaws. They look like A HUMAN FACE.

Gets up nervously and heads for the dor to the locker roo A whole row of lamps goes off. The rest flickers in and out. Then we see, now standing on her platform: THE OVERCOAT M He looks at her between a row of columns under the dead n lights. Susan tries the locker room door. It's unlocked.
carefully crosses the floor to the bank of lockers. She kneels to examine the hole in the wall.  She nears a noise. THE OVERCOAT MAN is moving toward her.
Peter?

The man's face TIPS BACK... ...raising the complex, glittering INSECT HEAD FROM BEHIN ITS MASK-LIKE FRONT JAWS. Its multi-parted MOUTH clicks OPEN. Susan SCREAMS! The thing charges, its "coat" opening to reveal...SIX LEATHERY WINGS, fully extended! The wingspan blocks the whole tunnel, they vibrate rapidly. Susan tries to run, but the creature -- hereafter known simply as "The Mimic" -- LEAPS ONTO HER CHEST! She's dragged screaming into the hole. Their silhouettes recede rapidly amidst a confusion of le wings and pipes.
Peter and Josh put the fecal samples into the back-pack. Leonard stands at the other end of the area. He inspects OLD SCAFFOLDING set up at an opening which leads to

head_text.subj: THE REMAINS OF AN OLD STATION

text: fifteen feet below.

I've never been this deep. This area here is the Old Armory station. They built it in the 40's. Ran out of money half-way through... It's like Grand Central's dead little brother. Tiled mosa walls, columns, monumental arches. Spaces for shops. A gr of abandoned turn-of-the-century subway cars on parallel tracks.
Okay, the fat lady's singing. Time to go. Everything is gray with dust.
(To Josh)

I want a team in here by six tonight, hands and knees with toothpicks... Leonard squints down at the planks of the scaffolding. A NYMPH -- big as the one seen earlier -- emerges from a of nearby feces as if it were part of the mound. Keeping his eyes fixed on the insect, Leonard coolly bend down, picks up a ROCK.
putting the last sample boxes into the back-pack, looks u and sees
step onto the scaffolding, raising the rock to crush the nymph.
Don't!! SMASH! Leonard tosses the rock at the insect, crushing it Peter rushes to the insect's corpse on the scaffolding.
Did you see the size of that thing?!
Look what you did! You stupid sonofa- A CREAK from the scaffolding at their combined weight. Leonard grabs Peter, tries to pull him from the scaffoldi
Buckling diagonally... ...taking Peter and Leonard with it... CRASH!  Both Peter and Leonard are thrown to the ground o the station below.  The scaffolding falls around them.
rushes forward.
Peter!
stir in the wreckage.  Peter rises shakily.  He puts his glasses on. One of the lenses is badly smashed.
It's okay.  I'm all right. He tries to help Leonard up; Leonard knocks his hand away
Get the hell away from me! Peter looks up at Josh.
(Deadpan)

He's all right, too. Leonard brushes himself off, checks out his walkie-talkie It's been broken in the fall, a tangle of plastic and wir He curses under his breath. Peter checks the wall for a handhold.  But there's only smooth tile and dust.
Oh, that's gonna work.
You got a better way up? Leonard removes his badge, tosses it up to Josh.
(To Josh.)
Show that to the station manager.  Tell him Leonard's gonna have his bubble-butt he don't have someone down here in ten.
H-how do I get...?
Way we came.  Take the first tunnel to your right... Leonard's voice echoes off the cavernous walls. Josh hurriedly writes it down in his notebook.
Go left.  Go left again till you hit the fork... Then right again. You got that?
I think so. One right, two lefts...
And a right.
Right.
Go Josh. Now. Josh obeys.

We hear a persistent BEEPING... A concrete ROOM filled with glimmering debris. Cans, eyeglasses, fake teeth, chrome, foil, glass shards, broke watches. Susan lies unconscious, half-sunk in a mulch of decomposi food, old newspapers, plastic garbage bags.  An inch of b WATER burbles past her bloody head. SOMETHING jostles her, rocking her back and forth. Her eyelids slowly open.

head_text.subj: A HUGE MIMIC IS PERCHED ON HER BODY

text: Its WINGCASE is drooped around her like a shroud. The creature furiously tears at her jacket, trying to get at Susan's beeper. The beeper spills from her pocket along with several Pay bars.  The Mimic CRUSHES the machine instantly, then chom up all the candy bars with a single move of its mandibles Susan watches in terror as the creature steps away. A SOUND from an adjacent tunnel.  Susan looks... ...and sees ANOTHER MIMIC pulling the REMAINS OF A MAN in the darkness. Susan gropes around her in the soggy debris, looking for weapon.
Her fingers close around a three-foot piece of RUSTY PIPE Something dark drips on her hand.
looks up. Above her, a badly decomposing HUMAN FOOT, or w is left of it.  All part of the excarnated corpse of the Chinese Preacher.  His gold cross shines boldly in the da Susan GASPS.
hears the sound.  It immediately SKITTERS back to her.

jerks herself sideways... AND STABS THE PIPE into the Mimic's thorax with a wet CRR Susan heaves herself up, pushing the thing onto its back. The Mimic BUZZES furiously, milky WHITE FOAM pumping from wound.  Its legs slash the air as it tries to right itsel Susan runs for the tunnels, debris falling from her cloth
comes to a t-junction.  He checks his notepad for the appropriate direction. He turns, heads left.

Susan staggers through a dark PASSAGEWAY.  Water drizzles into her grimy face.  She looks up. Rain leaks from an overhead grate three stories up.  She see the SHOES of PEOPLE walking to and fro above.

Life as usual on Delancey street. Pedestrians crisscross the metal grate, hunched under the umbrellas.  Traffic noise, T.V. displays on street front stores, boom boxes, car horns... They drown out the tiny sound of Susan's voice...
hears distant FEET SCURRYING toward her, punctuated by a metallic CLANG!  CLANG!  CLANG!
CLANG!  The metal pipe, still imbedded in the Mimic, BANG the wall as the insect moves down the dripping narrow tun

looks around frantically.  She crosses to a METAL LID on floor, lifts it. A HOLE is below, dropping off into darkness. The Mimic's CLANGING grows louder. Susan sits herself on the edge of the hole, grasping the metal lid by handles on its underside. The Mimic rushes into the chamber, speeding toward her... Susan JUMPS into the hole, hanging onto the lid... WHANG!  The lid SLAMS SHUT over the hole a fraction of a second before the creature reaches it. The Mimic touches the lid with its antennae, confused.
The TICK-TICKING of the Mimic's antennae scanning the lid Susan hangs from the handles on the lid, her arms trembli Susan's strength gives out.  She lets go, falls.
Susan CRASHES onto a juncture between two large PIPES. She MOANS in pain.

secures her position, looks down.  A seemingly bottomless below, crisscrossed with a FOREST OF PIPES AND DUCTS. The nearest pipe above her is well beyond reach. She is trapped. Then she hears the SOUND of the LID OPENING above.  She h her breath. A faint YELLOW LIGHT of a lighter flickers down at her.

Josh cautiously enters a vaulted area.  Old pipes have be ripped from the walls.  WATER gushes over the steel-plate walls.  He looks around- this doesn't seem familiar. Josh freezes as he sees something behind a loose metal PL on the wall. He yanks at the plate- it gives a little bit. He yanks harder- the plate falls down on one side, hanging precariously from a loose bolt. It reveals A HOLE PACKED WITH DOZENS AND DOZENS OF OOTHEC He leans close to examine them- there is a NOISE in the tunnel behind him-

A curtain of WATER falls over the side of a pipe onto the floor.  Behind it, something ENORMOUS crawls into view. Multiple legs, antennae, an elongated body distorted by t water and the light of a flare.  It stops-

Holding his breath and tiptoeing sideways, never taking h eyes off the thing, Josh begins to move away.  He sees a narrow OPENING in the wall- there seems to be dim LIGHT coming from something beyond it.  He tries to squeeze thr the opening-
The creature is immobile behind the sheet of water, as if mesmerized by its flow-

With tremendous effort, Josh passes through the opening. He finds himself inside a bowl-shaped mud hole.  Scattere around him he sees FUNNY BUNNY PATCHES that were sewn in sweatshop.  He trips on a half-buried SEWING MACHINE.  He looks up- Above him is a grate.  He's come to the SHOWER ROOM of th sweatshop!
Empty now, except for the rusting sewing machines in a corner.  We TILT to see Josh moving the grate away.  He jumps- no way he can grab onto the slippery tile-
Josh puts the old sewing machine upright.
Suddenly, the bolt hinging the plate gives way and... the steel plate hits the ground: KLANGG!!
leaps into action!
hears the CLICKING, fairly close.  He shines his light ba down the hole he entered through-
moves past the waterfall and takes the wall at full speed
Oh shit, oh shit, oh shit! He stands on top of the sewing machine, wobbling, reaches the floor above-
Josh's head and one shoulder are in through the hole.  Hi arms tremble. He makes a desperate lunge and manages to g the POWER CORD of one of the abandoned sewing machines.
rushes through the opening without even slowing down.

pulls himself up, up-  WHAM!  The Mimic hits the lower pa of his body, BLOOD spraying up through the hole.  He SCRE grasps the cord with both hands! He is brutally YANKED down into the hole, the sewing mach tipping, then dragged across the tiled floor till it wedg violently in the hole! We track over to reveal, one of Chuy's perfectly executed WIRE SCULPTURES. Sitting atop another sewing machine.

A ring of FLARES burns in the darkness like an island.  P lights another one, revealing a space buried in layers of dust and time. Cracked MANNEQUIN FACES stares out from an unopened TAILO SHOP.  A FLOWER PARLOR decorated with cobwebs.  A yellowe NEWSPAPER on the floor, its headlines reading:  GERMAN TR DRIVEN BACK ACROSS RHINE. Peter looks up to see Leonard approaching from the track.
Any luck?

Well...there's an old service elevator half a mile down the tracks.  Ain't gonna be much use, though.  Lines are dead. Peter shines his flare up at a thick cord of cables which ominously with electricity.
You said those cables're still live. Can't we rewire...?
Oh, man, there you go again.
What?
Those things bring juice to the new stations.  You just can't rewire that shit... Peter approaches him.
For Chrissakes, what's the problem? You need a memo every time you fart?
All right, motherfucker, that's it. He pushes Peter violently. Their eyes lock and meet. Inches away from a fistfight.

Shh! Shh! A SOUND rushing towards them, its echoes increasing by th second. Where is it coming from? Peter looks at Leonard.  Leonard unbuttons his holster cl places his hand on his .22 A SHADOW appears outside the archway. It steps onto the platform. Leonard frowns.
(tentative)
Manny?! The old man stumbles out of the darkness, out of breath. rusted crowbar in his hand. Leonard walks over to him solicitously.
My God, what the hell are you...?
Hurry, the woman needs help! A shadow crosses Peter's face.
Woman?

OUTSTRETCHED HANDS in the darkness. REVEAL Peter leaning across the void with one hand while Manny and Leonard grip his other. Susan below, balancing precariously on the crisscrossing pipes. A mess, but still alive.  She reaches up to Peter. It's too far.
(A whisper)
Don't.
Listen to me:  we're getting you out. Leonard and Manny pull Peter back into
Peter undoes his belt.
(To Manny and Leonard)
Give me your belts. They obey. Peter buckles them together with his. He then loops one end around a bannister, the other around his wr
(to Manny, as he ties them together)
What are you doing down here?
Chuy. He was taken. He's down here somewhere... (to Peter)
Oh, please, hurry. I saw what was after her.
What's...?

Just hurry. Peter takes his word for it.  He uses the belts to lower himself to the nearest pipe. Leonard LIGHTS a flare to illuminate the pipe gallery. Peter works his way down. The web of pipes seem to recede into Hades. The lifeline tightens. Peter gets to the last solid footing, lies down on his stomach and lets the belts down.
I'm coming, Sus, I'm coming. But then, he sees something move below her. Then a hollow
No, Jesus, no.
(To Leonard)
Toss the flare down!
I only got...
Just do it! Leonard lets the flare drop from his hand. It falls past them, ricocheting off the maze of pipes, spinning down to the pitch-black below. And for a split second the flame illuminates...
pipe in its thorax, nimbly CLIMBING THE PIPES TOWARD SUSA
eyes grow huge.
Oh, Jesus...
just plain loses it.
What the fuck is that?! What the fuck is that?!
knows all too well what's coming for her.
(A desperate appeal)
Peter... Throwing caution to the wind, Peter reaches the belt down
Wrap it around your hand! Susan at last gets a grip.  Peter pulls with both arms. CLANG! CLANG! CLANG! Getting closer.
Come on! Susan struggles for footholds on the slippery pipes, ascending foot by foot... Peter pulls her into his arms.
Peter bends down.
Get on my shoulders! Susan steps onto his shoulders.  He pushes her up... And Leonard and Manny yank her out.
Peter scrambles up, SLAMS the lid back on the hole.
Let's go! The four of them run. HOLD ON the lid. WHAM! It bursts from the floor, rolls away like a coin.
The four humans run down the empty platform.  Peter spare look back.
Oh, shit... Far down the tunnel,

head_text.subj: THE MIMIC HAS SPREAD ITS WINGS AND IS FLYING AFTER THEM

text: There! He points to the open DOOR of an ancient SUBWAY CAR. They sprint for the car, get to the door.  Manny, Peter, Leonard, then Susan...
...tumble inside a repair car crammed with shelves and em crates.

Get the goddam door! Leonard and Peter both grab its handle, slide it shut... SPLACK!  The Mimic crashes into it! KLANGGG!  The door bulges out from the impact, almost tearing itself off the hinges.
